title: English Language Arts: Grades 9-10
subject: English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects (2024-)

document.title: Iowa Academic Standards for English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects

353D75B07C0C4B1D9789AA8FC16CF07B.description:
Acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for
reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate
independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to
comprehension or expression.

29D21262DDEE4253A1EB431FC5CFC7CF.description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

8870EF187D0E4098BF34362C06CEDA8B.description:
Interpret figures of speech (e.g., euphemism, oxymoron, verbal irony, satire, idiom, paradox) in
context and analyze their role in the text.

A253796B07BE4593BF4A3B4764852067.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

31AF7D34989143529BF8F477FD0E1533.description:
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the
inferred meaning in context or by using other reference materials).

F053004FD8694F3F95AC4495D5C7F302.description:
Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries,
thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its
precise meaning, its part of speech, or its etymology.

FC1029C1E9974DA9B37BAF18D851BB33.description:
Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of
speech (e.g., analyze, analysis, analytical; advocate, advocacy).

D131587364084182BF670FF923CAB9D2.description:
Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word’s position or
function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

640F9383E5444CA8BC18C9747D59D041.description:
Use a variety of strategies to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words
and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content.

2761AE09B9C84F749788E19A1011CB05.description:
Write and edit work so that it conforms to the guidelines in a style manual (e.g., MLA Handbook,
APA Style) appropriate for the discipline and writing type.

4DE893F292204E87945AB07D36CEBC09.description:
Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make
effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

9733E681C9884B3EB193D7D602DCB892.description: Spell correctly, consulting references as needed.

4D5998F993264A01A33378BB4332F564.description: Use a colon to introduce a list or quotation.

D906A4F4A0C847ABA5E82D58304C6C9D.description:
Use a semicolon (and perhaps a conjunctive adverb) to link two or more closely related
independent clauses.

716A6268CA904F798A9D99A61087C761.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling
when writing.

87DE7641FB5A46B38007BBF3BF5EDD05.description:
Use various types of phrases (noun, verb, adjectival, adverbial, participial, prepositional,
absolute) and clauses (independent, dependent; noun, relative, adverbial) to convey specific
meanings and add variety and interest to writing or presentations.

86F1E557D82E42E5B9BF152A112E0781.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or
speaking.

89FF2991303F4F39AE87EB477ADF21D1.description:
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, such as conducting interviews, participating in public
performances, or debating an issue from either side, demonstrating command of formal English when
indicated or appropriate; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation. (See
grades 9–10 Language standards 1 and 3 for specific expectations)

3AA1AD26775742D48356BA010493AFA5.description:
Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in
presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

C4051E2EBD92412AAB2A3EA56D933648.description:
Present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically such that
listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, substance, and style are
appropriate to purpose, audience, and task.

F39508B65D444DF0B8C7734DDB554A34.description:
Evaluate a speaker’s point of view (perspective), reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric,
identifying any fallacious reasoning or exaggerated or distorted evidence.

899E739EF52D44CB99C521842F072FE4.description:
Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse media or formats (e.g., visually,
quantitatively, orally), evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source.

5F13EBC88B4144718A9EE57749B58A77.description:
Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives, summarize points of agreement and
disagreement, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views and understanding and
make new connections in light of the evidence and reasoning presented.

1A41D2ABA70A48A8B9609F8DAE64EBE5.description:
Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that relate the current discussion
to broader themes or larger ideas; actively incorporate others into the discussion; and clarify,
verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions.

071068E09E7C429D9B6F1E0CE1D7E434.description:
Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision-making (e.g., informal
consensus, taking votes on key issues, presentation of alternate views), clear goals and
deadlines, and individual roles as needed.

967FBE81E8CC497BB66C0F488099A874.description:
Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly
draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or
issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas.

59CA43335A6041F0BB06A11D5410E931.description:
Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and
teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 9–10 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas
and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

ED7D23B73AA8425CA03B3FA928B2D507.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time
frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences, scaffolding as
needed.

9654DC79FEE6485E8B625485A4C17A0F.description:
Apply grades 9–10 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., “Delineate and evaluate the
argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the
evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify any false statements and fallacious reasoning”).

D8372DFBDBFF4D3B82A903063997D8D2.description:
Apply grades 9–10 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Analyze how an author draws on and
transforms source material in a specific work.”).

F03F3CFCF10C493E976F653CA4ACC7D1.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

1D85DA7CE9334EF095011E808D075933.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple credible primary and secondary authoritative print and digital
sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the usefulness of each source in answering the
research question; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding
plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

14FB6A652B8745799A961F108DDE5534.description:
Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a selfgenerated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize
multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

B3D2102E69574D6293F18DE101E1F0AA.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

A190814DDBE64A31B3E42949CC033680.description:
Use technology to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products, taking advantage
of technology’s capacity to link to other information and to display information flexibly and dynamically.

393BD5751FFD42119FF8959395A02FEF.description:
Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new
approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience. (Editing
for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3 up to and including grades
9–10.)

9BE08A5B96AD4970BCE8479703AAB5CE.description:
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to
task, purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–
3 above).

662B377AD52D4CECA4B0C600565C231B.description:
Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or
resolved over the course of the narrative.

E6DE80BB577D408AA8A060B95050F07E.description:
Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture
of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

6C46AB6C2C85431399C811E7FFC79694.description:
Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a
coherent whole (e.g., flashback, foreshadowing, and cause and effect).

589C5CD313C442C0A15766523DCAC25F.description:
Use narrative techniques, including dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot
lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters; create a smooth progression of
experiences or events.

A3424A100A9444D5883D36ED4DF88CEA.description:
Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its
significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or
characters.

F5358616E44A412CBD40405455CCD3E0.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

2A19AACD9BA843629886A7EB7856EF41.description:
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or
explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

314F87E44E4E49DFADB5CDFB4B47042B.description:
Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and
conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

4E18D36D944940A3B07B9FED4E948D98.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to manage the complexity of the topic.

BA7BAD0334884196ABFB14069DBF939B.description:
Use appropriate and varied transitions to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion,
and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

7010C2649FE7442E92AEACC309391F32.description:
Develop the topic with well-chosen, relevant, and sufficient facts, extended definitions, concrete
details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience’s knowledge
of the topic.

42FBC2CE636E45EB8DAFD366C548CBEA.description:
Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information to make important
connections and distinctions; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables),
and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

8212EE535FB14C14AA3478F7E55F98B1.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information
clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

023272C03F224195880630F7E4F35E3C.description:
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument
presented.

592D93B47434413F80220048C1911250.description:
Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and
conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

652D2B1EB0C14ED8A2F40F9EA08EA4F5.description:
Use words, phrases, and clauses to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and
clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and
between claim(s) and counterclaims.

33F4F988101341CB83EE27E053C70DF3.description:
Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly, supplying evidence for each while pointing out the
strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience’s knowledge level
and concerns.

84F24E4897984069A227449483668632.description:
Introduce precise claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create
an organization that establishes clear relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons,
and evidence.

900EC2CE5EA040DA9E29C903DCEF9CDA.description:
Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning
and relevant and sufficient evidence.

64FC6CA0DE8D4C71AA7E28547D7C76B8.description:
By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 9–10 text complexity band
proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 9–10 text
complexity band independently and proficiently.

86A6BDAA6D6B4C3F8570A2E4C7D07E2B.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

363D03BD737D4BE499B128C159B946EB.description:
Analyze seminal U.S. documents of historical and literary significance, including how they address
related themes and concepts.

B3999FF3D3914401B69CE64293697B55.description:
Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is
valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify any false statements and fallacious reasoning.

4235DC54AA8D4E2B8C44AA904C4C7170.description:
Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums (e.g., a person’s life story in both print
and multimedia), determining which details are emphasized in each account.

28FAEA4C807140279784833496A455D0.description:
Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to
advance that point of view or purpose.

73D777081CFF499CAD50B398322CA9BB.description:
Analyze in detail how an author’s ideas or claims are developed by particular sentences, paragraphs, or
larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).

A9EFD073F9F748A9A9E49FAED9913BEC.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative,
connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on
meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper).

16673A2671144270A8D9D056F76B3576.description:
Analyze how the author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which
the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the connections that are drawn
between them.

627D559EFAE44D6491A76CDF60DD9007.description:
Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including
how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

4E7F435EEA7A457687DEF9CC8372BEA6.description:
Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as
inferences drawn from the text.

3A20CA7E23B6460F9F003ED9F3B5826A.description:
By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the
grades 9-10 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the
high end of the grades 9-10 text complexity band proficiently.

9DBF1E885EC740A18456D26B004F2F34.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

85A71DECF19E414593CA55067E17CFBF.description: Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work.

9C334EAE1F63446F850E397EF73EDABF.description:
Analyze the representation of a subject or a key scene in two different artistic mediums, including what
is emphasized or absent in each treatment.

C46BB40F7CCC42AC8D72FB3BCB5D77E1.description:
Analyze a particular point of view, perspective, or cultural experience reflected in a work of literature
from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature.

C39396FA1BBE452AB470B7FE7ECF8576.description:
Analyze how an author’s choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it (e.g., parallel
plots), and manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or
surprise.

EA9E3444E5E24C3D97EC53752F4DE545.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and
connotative meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone
(e.g., how the language evokes a sense of time and place; how it sets a formal or informal tone).

90420886D2F74C0C87A1A9D9F5D8CB5C.description:
Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the
course of a text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.

8A3AE211E9A947AEB849A85216611D66.description:
Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the
text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective
summary of the text.

B8C4DCEE9BD149609CC57201DEE9C386.description:
Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as
inferences drawn from the text.
